top_comment.text:
I'm a little torn on this one. I'll admit I smoke pot and I don't live in a 
state where it is legal.

But I think it comes down to:
A) Is someone criminally responsible for violating a law that has and will 
be found to be unjust? 
B) Should someone be released for knowingly violating a law that existed at 
the time?

Like I said, I do smoke pot. But I do so knowing that I could be arrested 
and I have been arrested for possession. Regardless of if the law changes, 
I knew what I was doing was illegal whether I thought it was just or not. 
Should my conviction be wiped from my record?

Part of me says that these people should be released and part of me says 
that these people (like myself) knew that they were violating the law. 

I guess another point would be; why when it is illegal federally should one 
states "criminals" get a pass when people who do the same thing in other 
states don't?

I personally think it should be legal federally, however until it is I 
don't see how a state can bypass federal law to give their citizens 
immunity that doesn't apply to inhabitants of other states. It seems like 
they get "special" treatment federally because of the state that they live 
in.

It's a very rare situation where the federal government doesn't enforce the 
law on the state level, but it seems like they are discriminating against 
most other states and their citizens with this ruling. If you are in say 
Illinois, you will stay in jail because it is illegal, but if you like in 
Colorado you don't have to live by the same federal rules.﻿
top_comment.author: recklessmb

comments.text:
+TheRobster2007 But how can it only apply to some Americans and not apply 
to others? It's still a federal law. My problem is that they are excusing 
some Americans of violating a federal law when others don't get the same 
treatment.
comments.author: recklessmb

top_comment.text:
Isn't releasing people jailed over this drug a bit of a slippery slope? 
Maybe it's only in my head, but don't you think that if they do that there 
would also be some sort of outcry or legal attack (like a class action 
lawsuit or something) by those who want to have their arrest records purged 
over this drug as well? Seems like there's going to be a heck of a lot of 
hassle in their future.

Personally, I don't see the point in trying to release those in jail over 
the drug. At the time they were buying, selling, or growing it was illegal 
and they *did* break the law even if the law changed. *Maybe* they should 
lighten obviously heavy sentences, but that doesn't change the fact that 
they broke the law. If you don't change the sentencing of those already 
sentenced after sentencing requirements changed then why would you release 
law-breakers just because the law they were already tried over changed? I 
just don't get it.﻿

comments.author: wwwpwndcom

comments.text: You're right. This may be a slippery slope that slides into justice.
comments.author: Mark Feigenbutz

comments.text:
+Blow-Up Bunny Generally, no. In a functional society, laws are written to 
enhance the quality of life for its' citizens. In practice, the law applies 
to you equally whether you agree with it or not, but there are 
circumstances where the experiences from decades of trials and observation 
done while the law was fully active, tell us that the law wasn't actually 
enhancing the overall quality of life for its' citizens.

One example from history of such a law is the prohibition of alcohol from 
the 30's. Afterward, it was easy to see that the ones who benefitted the 
most from alcohol being illegal, were the criminals who smuggled it. The 
enforcement of that law also cost tremendous sums of taxpayer money. Sure, 
it's reasonable to say that alcohol can cause societal problems, like drunk 
driving and violent crimes, but apparently, making it illegal didn't have 
the positive effect they were hoping for.

The weed laws are quite similar, and the problems with wasted tax money are 
still here, but medically, the ill effects of marijuana are far less than 
those of alcohol. I say some problems should be dealt with by other means 
than illegalizing them.
comments.author: bonkoboy

comments.text:

consider countries where it is illegal to be gay or an atheist. If the law 
was changed to allow it, would you not allow previous offenders free?

Saudi Arabia, it's illegal for women to drive cars. Wouldn't you pardon

comments.text:
because of hemp, corporations and racism:

Hemp provides oil for lubrication and making paint, seeds for human and 
animal food, pulp for making paper and fibers for making rope and cloth. In 
fact, you can get four times the paper pulp from an acre of hemp than from 
an acre of trees--- and hemp will grow back in one year.

Chemical and industrial interests were against this. They used a scare 
campaign and yellow journalism that claimed "Negroes" would lust after 
white women after smoking it.

Drug companies would rather sell you expensive pills for relieving pain and 
nausea, pills that might get you hooked, rather than letting you grow 
something better in your backyard.

The first anti-marijuana laws in the US were in the Southwest and 
deliberately targeted Mexicans who smoked it.

another. the major point being: even if possession of personal amounts of 
marijuana is still an offence to some degree in a given country, you're not 
going to go to jail or get a criminal record for that offence.

that way"*

No. You are the fucking idiot. As long as cannabis was illegal, people who 
bought the substance were funding gangs and organized crime. Said 
activities are responsible for about 50% of homicides in the US. As for the 
idea that cannabis is safer than cigarettes, that's just moronic. Smoking 
cannabis has exactly the same negative effects as smoking tobacco as the 
problems primarily are related to inhaling hot smoke. In addition to that, 
we can also be entirely confident that cannabis is one of the major causal 
factors in a fair number of accidents, similar to how alcohol is, due to 
its detrimental effects on people's reasoning power and reaction time.
comments.author: Gnomefro

comments.text:
+Kamikaze Keeg *"There's no logical reason to keep them in jail for 
something that isn't a crime anymore"*

Sure there can be. Here are two:

* Demanding respect for whatever the law is at any given time. Pot smokers 
made the conscious decision to risk jail time for their actions as well as 
making the decision to fund organized crime by buying the substance.

* Legalization may have other reasons behind it than "Pot is really the 
greatest thing ever". For example, it could be legalized to undermine 
income to criminal gangs. If so, the consensus could still be that pot 
smokers were damaging society and deserve jail time.
comments.author: Gnomefro

comments.text:

comments.text:
+Pavel Blaszkiewicz Unfortunately, an understanding of this channel is 
dependent on basic critical thinking skills and an ability to determine the 
validity of an argument.  Here's a quick lesson:

"Many people have died from overdose on drugs and weed. Its just a fact 
that everyone knows that drugs kill."
--- There's not a single case of a person overdosing on weed.  Not one.
--- You then say "drugs and weed."  No other drugs are being discussed.
--- Nothing you said is "just a fact," so if "everybody knows it," it's 
still wrong.

But best of all: "Many people have died from overdose on *alcohol*. Its 
just a fact that everyone knows that *alcohol* kills."

I read an estimate some years ago that alcohol contributes to 75,000 deaths 
a year in the US.  Some 35,000 were alcohol-related diseases (liver 
failure, mostly), and the rest were car crashes and other accidents.

Reason, that thing you lack, leads one to question why a drug as dangerous 
as alcohol is legal in the first place.  This inevitably results in the 
realization that criminalizing marijuana is absurd and incredibly 
hypocritical.

top_comment.text:
*I agree that they should be released* however it is kinda murky territory 
when you look at it from a different perspective.  That is, they weren't 
necessarily sent to jail for possession of marijuana but instead because 
there was a law against said possession and by possessing it they *broke 
the law*, therefore they've been incarcerated for breaking the law, and to 
release them now would not be much different than creating a new law and 
retrospectively sending people to jail who would have broken the law had it 
been in place at the time.  Essentially this other perspective points out 
that it should go both ways.  When slavery was abolished those who had been 
slavers didn't get sent to jail because they hadn't broken any laws. 
 People are in jail for breaking the law, regardless of what law it was. 
 They broke the law and are now in jail for it.  If marijuana becomes 
criminalized again would the people who were released then be made to 
finish their sentences?﻿
top_comment.author: Sicstix

another perspective.  You are on some sort of witch hunt and quick to put

ever come to meeting you since I imagine a friendship with you would be 
quite taxing full of conversations that run in circles as you take things 
out of context and try to dictate other peoples thoughts and feelings.
u.u
Me: "See this cube, if you look at it from this side it's red, from this 
side it's blue, from this side it's yellow, from this side it's green, 
etc..."
You: "You said the cube is blue!!! But it is really multi-colored!!"
Me: "No, I said it was blue when you look at it from this perspective, 
maybe you should re-read what I posted"
You: "I did read it, you said it was blue!!!"

top_comment.author: alonzo9772

comments.text:
+Dyvim Tvar
Yes. I just think we have too many value systems that clash with each other 
to make that feasible right now. We have our *moral* values, we have 
*scientific* facts and we have a *market* value system; sometimes none of 
them are in sync. It can be difficult to know how to best benefit human 
society in such a dilemma.

A *moral system* (meaning, a system used in a society that respects and 
protects the individual, enforcing justice and fairness in general) renders 
safety, happiness and therefore, productivity.
A *scientific system* cares about what's true, and provides knowledge to 
inform our decisions.
A *market system* allows for interactions that are mutually 
beneficial between individuals and societies, and provides a monetary 
standard for evaluating the worth of a product or service.

In capitalism, which is the financial system used today, the *market value* 
is the only value taken into account, which creates many situations where 
the most financially beneficial choice neither conforms with moral values 
or with what is scientifically sound. That is the most important hurdle to 
overcome, in my opinion.
comments.author: bonkoboy
